div.p: My time at school was difficult because I can only walk a limited amount, when I was younger I could only walk like about a metre or so
without getting tired; it was very difficult I was always picked on, I used to be very overweight because I used to spend my time in a wheelchair
yeah I used to be picked on, called names so when I was, say, about 14 or 15 I decided to go on a strict diet and start working out and my dad said
“start defending yourself” so he taught me how to, I know it’s a bit naughty, but he taught me how to fight and stick up for myself
yeah so it was quite difficult.
About 7 I would say so I spent about a year at normal school, probably 2 years, at normal school and I was kind of selected out;
my mum and dad were seeing whether I could cope, I had the intelligence there but given that I have to think about what I’m writing
and that sort of thing I was kind of slipping behind, my mum said I had the intelligence but teachers couldn’t cope because I was
slipping behind because of my writing and that sort of thing, yeah. Me and my friend at the time, Dominic, were the only people with
a physical disability, walking, people that went to my Special School were outcasts, were trouble makers, so there were people
who had problems with authority, people that used to break into places, you know, people that just couldn’t cope with school...
